6/ Big things matter. I know they do. I fill my days working on big things. 

But small things - the kind words, the little favor, the easy compliment, the hug - matter more to those on the receiving end than any of us know.

Today, more than other days, that‚Äôs worth remembering.

5/ Daniel didn‚Äôt come home on the bus that afternoon. 

He died, 7 years ago today, in his first grade classroom. 

But what he did that morning - the hugs, the cuddling, the holding hands - are, for his family, perhaps the most important things he ever did.

4/ On the walk to the bus stop with his dad, he didn‚Äôt want to play their usual game of tag. 

‚ÄúCan we just hold hands today?‚Äù He asked. 

So they did.

3/ Back inside, his dad told him he could go back to bed, but Daniel wouldn‚Äôt. He wanted to cuddle with his dad. 

When his sister left for school, and his mom left for work, they got big hugs too. So nice, they remember, because often Daniel was still asleep when they left.

2/ Daniel never awoke before his beloved older brother, who got on the bus at 6:20 each morning. 

But on Dec.14, 2012, implausibly, he did. He hustled down the driveway in his pjs and flip flops, and hugged his brother goodbye. 

‚ÄúThe only time that ever happened‚Äù, said his dad.

I want to tell you a story. An important story.

And then I want you to share it.

To help people understand why the small things we do matter - amidst all the big things that seem so insurmountable and scary.

1/ I want to tell you what 7 yr old Daniel did, 7 yrs ago today.

China agrees to buy $50B of ag products next year, increase of $29B from pre-tariff trade.

So...we lost/spent $39B. Gained $29B.

Ultimately, the only way to succeed in a place like Afghanistan is (a) not bite off more than you can chew; keep your goals limited; and (b) give political tasks to diplomats, not soldiers.

The Afghanistan papers paint a bleak picture of a drug policy there that never had a coherent direction.

But the problem wasn't a bad plan. The problem is that 21 year old Commandos can't execute the nuanced work of transitioning an entire country off their primary cash crop.

So the U.S. is in Parmakan, protecting the fields that supply the Taliban with the money to fight the U.S., and victory is defined by slightly trimming the profits of the trade?

"That's f'd up" I say to one of our soldiers.

"That's Afghanistan," he says back.

"Before the U.S. came here, the Taliban would come to our town and steal it," he continued. "But now, with your troops here, the Taliban pays us."

Our delegation starts scratching our heads.

The locals walk us through the town, and we notice it is blanketed by fields covered in beautiful flowers. It is, of course, poppy. Everywhere the eye can see.

"Who do you sell it to?" we ask.

"The Taliban," says a village leader.

DoD took us out to a small town in western Afghanistan to see the Afghan "surge". A few dozen Commandos had moved into a small town - Parmakan - to protect the locals from the Taliban. These guys were bright and brave.
